comments.content:
Detailed report: https://oss-fuzz.com/testcase?key=4519542728425472

Project: openssl
Fuzzer: libFuzzer_openssl_x509
Fuzz target binary: x509
Job Type: libfuzzer_asan_openssl
Platform Id: linux

Crash Type: Heap-buffer-overflow READ 1
Crash Address: 0x602000000411
Crash State:
  X509v3_addr_get_afi
  i2r_IPAddrBlocks
  X509V3_EXT_print
  
Sanitizer: address (ASAN)

Recommended Security Severity: Medium

Regressed: https://oss-fuzz.com/revisions?job=libfuzzer_asan_openssl&range=201612232021:201612240725

Reproducer Testcase: https://oss-fuzz.com/download?testcase_id=4519542728425472

Issue filed automatically.

See https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/blob/master/docs/reproducing.md for more information.

This bug is subject to a 90 day disclosure deadline. If 90 days elapse
without an upstream patch, then the bug report will automatically
become visible to the public.

When you fix this bug, please
  * mention the fix revision(s).
  * state whether the bug was a short-lived regression or an old bug in any stable releases.
  * add any other useful information.
This information can help downstream consumers.

If you have questions for the OSS-Fuzz team, please file an issue at https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/issues.
A fix for this is available.
Kurt@, can you please comment on the security implications of this. This looks like a long standing bug.
We're debating if we should assign a CVE to this or not, and at which severity we would look at this. We will probably look at this as a LOW.
Can it be used for an arbitrary 1 byte read.

No, it can only be used for a one-byte read directly after the parsed IPAddress structure. While it is a public routine, it needn't be; it's only used in crypto/x509v3/v3_addr.c and is only used to determine how to output data about the extension.

We're issuing CVE 2017-3735, and the fix, today.  We're calling it LOW.
It looks like a day-one bug, dating back to commit 96ea4ae9 made in 2006.

rich.salz@, thanks for the fix!
Once ClusterFuzz confirms the fix, the bug will be auto-closed and will become public in 30 days (and so the reproducer input will also become public). 
Meanwhile, I've been asked to provide the input now, w/o waiting for 30 days. 
https://twitter.com/hanno/status/902426281354113024

Is it ok to make the input public now, or we better wait?

I was under the impression that it was 7 days after it's closed?

I was preparing a new update of the fuzz corpora in the openssl repo, but that at least going to take a few days. I've been able to reproduce it a few times when the input wasn't added yet, and one input has been added to my local corpus since yesterday.

I currently don't see why we shouldn't make this public.

30 days now. (7 days was the very early version of the policy)

Thanks, done. 
https://github.com/google/fuzzer-test-suite/tree/master/openssl-1.1.0c#x509

ClusterFuzz has detected this issue as fixed in range 201708280414:201708291730.
